newsitem.title: MEXICO: Mexico stocks end up on data and Dow gains.
newsitem.headline: Mexico stocks end up on data and Dow gains.

text.p: The Mexican bourse closed sharply hgiher Thursday as favourable economic data drew bargain hunters into the market.
The leading IPC share index ended up 47.90 points, or 1.27 percent, at 3,821.92.
"It was time stocks recovered a little after the recent slump on the Dow and company earnings," a trader said.
The Dow Jones industrial average ended up 50.97 points at 7,136.62, after rising as high as 7,236.96.
The Finance Ministry announced in early trade it had revised Mexico's trade surplus for March up to $636 million from a preliminary figure of $565 million.
In the closing minutes, Banco de Mexico announced the consumer price index increased 1.08 percent, or slightly below an average rise of 1.11 precent forecast in a Reuters survey.

"The market reacted to a favourable macroeconomic backdrop, trade balance and inflation data were good. Furthermore, several blue chips had lagged far behind the market, and that also triggered buying," an equity analyst said.
Trading volume was moderate at 77.9 million shares. Dealers said dealing was not brisk for the day as a whole, but did pick up in late trade.
"Volume wasn't great, but we were rushed off our feet after midday," a desk trader said.
Bancomer, one of Mexico's biggest financial groups, was the most actively trade stock of the day and ended up five centavos (less than 1 cent) at 2.85 pesos (36 cents).
Dealers noted that Banacci, another major financial group, ended down 16 centavos (2 cents) at 16.64 pesos ($2.10).
"Banacci is less volatile, and less subject to day-to-day changes, but seemed to suffer from expectations domestic rates will rise from their current floor level," a trader said.
Telmex also weighed heavily on the upside, dealers said. The telecomms firm ended up 16 centavos (2 cents) at 16.50 pesos ($2.09) after tracking its ADRs, which gained 3/8 to 41-5/8 on Wall Street.
On the broad market, 115 stocks changed hands, of which 63 gained while 26 declined.
Debt stricken conglomerate Grupo Sidek led the prominent gainers, followed by its tourist arm Situr.
Sidek gained six centavos (less than 1 cent) to 42 centavos (5 cents), while Situr gained nine centavos (1 cent) to 34 centavos (4 cents).
